statement:
Let $H$ and $K$ be subgroups of a group $G$. Every double coset $HgK$,
with $g \in G$, is a union of or left cosets, since $$\begin{aligned}
HgK = \bigcup_{k \in K} Hgk\; = \bigcup_{h \in H} hgK,\end{aligned}$$
but these unions need not be disjoint. In particular, from the above
equality we cannot say how many right (or left) cosets fit in a double
coset.

The following proposition aims to clarify this.

$\,$

[ **-**]{} Let $H$ and $K$ be subgroups of a group $G$ and $g \in G$. We
have that $$\begin{aligned}
HgK = \bigcup_{[k]\, \in\, (K \cap g^{-1}Hg) \backslash K} Hgk\; = \bigcup_{[h]\, \in\, H / (H \cap gKg^{-1})} hgK\end{aligned}$$
hold as disjoint unions. In particular, the number of right and left
cosets in $HgK$ is respectively given by $$\begin{aligned}
\#(H \backslash HgK) = [K: K \cap g^{-1}Hg]\\
\#(HgK/K) =[H: H \cap gKg^{-1}]\end{aligned}$$

Remarks
-------

-   The number of right and left cosets in a double coset does not
    coincide in general, not for double cosets of the form $HgH$.

[9]{} A. Krieg, **, Mem. Amer. Math. Soc., no. 435, vol. 87, 1990.
names: left and right cosets in a double coset
